awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Can Regularization of Former Squatters Transition Them into Urban Citizens?
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the history of urban growth, legalization of urban squatters, and its effects on developing communities. The research will examine how different governments evaluated the issue of squatting and framed it to the public; it will identify for whom and why states legalized squatting; and it will assess the effects of legalization, including compliance and resistance.  


Research will be multi-method, including archival research, quantitative analysis of community characteristics and state responses, and qualitative interviews. The co-PI will remain on-site in two locations for several months to collect these data. The research helps re-theorize state-building, contributes to the literature on symbolic governance, and identifies the effects of extending urban citizenship under differing conditions.

por.por_cntn:
This research supports a dissertation project examining the political development of urban clientelism in 20th century Latin America, focusing on the capital cities of Lima, Peru, Caracas, Venezuela, and (with additional support from the Social Science Research Council) Mexico City. Clientelism--an informal and hierarchical type of authority relations between well-resourced political elites and relatively-poor clients, often mediated by brokers--has been an important aspect of the politics of modern Latin America and has shaped the nature of citizenship in that region and beyond. Despite its substantive importance, however, until now it has not been studied comparatively and historically with an eye to explaining its origins, variants, extent, and limits.

Urban clientelism arose in 20th century Latin America and beyond due to the rapid and massive influx of rural inhabitants to major urban centers. Lacking economic means to purchase residences, the new urban poor requisitioned land and established vast self-built squatter settlements, especially in the periphery of capital cities. Urban brokers arose to mediate between the state and political parties, on the one hand, and the new urban poor, on the other. This research is the first to systematically compare varieties of clientelism and urban brokers’ authority vis-à-vis the state and squatters.

In addition to drawing from the existing research on the three cases, this study is based on three kinds of original evidence: (1) petitions and letters written by squatters, settlement leaders, and urban brokers; (2) government reports and circulars about squatter settlements; and (3) press and other contemporaneous third-party sources. The co-Principal Investigator spent about six months in each city collecting these sources. Since this is the first comparative study of 20th century urban clientelism in Latin America, and since they were collected specifically for this project, many of these sources have never before been used, and none of them have been used as they are in this project.

These data provide a means to assess the main explanatory theories for urban clientelism--namely, weak-state, residual-ruralism, and resource-patronage theories--in an effort to account for qualitative differences in urban clientelisms and in the extent of urban brokers’ power. While definitive findings will have to await the completion of data analysis, provisional analysis suggests that the existing theories help explain qualitative differences in the nature of urban clientelism but do poorly at explaining urban brokers’ power. The latter was greatest in Mexico City by the 1970s and 1980s probably due to urban brokers’ ability to pitch generations of squatters against one another. This greater ability seems to have been borne of that city’s more-extensive squatter settlement urbanization.

Many observers have noted that legalization of urban squatter residences can change the nature of authority relations between the state and squatters--turning squatters into “urban citizens.” Legalization initiatives were undertaken in Mexico City in the 1980s, in Lima in the 1990s, and in Caracas in the 2000s--in pursuit of "popular capitalism" and "21st century socialism" in Peru and Venezuela respectively. Nevertheless, patterns of urban clientelism seem to have persisted, undergirding populism and enabling urban brokers’ continued power. Thus, to better understand the political impact of legalization requires greater attention to the growth and persistence of urban clientelism.
